title: The Questions We No Longer Ask
notes:
Why does inertia exist?
Where do physical constants come from?
Why are some questions treated as unnecessary rather than unanswered?

This reflection isn’t about rejecting modern physics — it’s about remembering what used to drive it.

At some point, certain foundational questions quietly disappeared from mainstream discussion. Not because they were resolved, but because we were told they no longer needed to be asked.

Cosmic Relativity enters this conversation not as a final answer, but as a reminder — a doorway that reopens curiosity and allows us to ask “why” again, without apology.

This is a reflection on curiosity, permission, and the cultural shift that taught us to stop asking the most basic questions about the world we inhabit.

Not to argue.
Not to convince.
But to notice what we may have lost along the way.

title: How We Lost Our Way of Thinking
notes:
At some point, something shifted.

Not all at once.
Not loudly.
But gradually enough that we barely noticed it happening.

This isn’t a video about blaming technology, politics, or any one idea.
It’s a reflection on something more subtle.  How layers of abstraction, models, systems, and narratives slowly replaced our direct relationship with the world itself.

How tools meant to help us understand reality quietly became more important than reality.

This is not an argument, and it’s not a diagnosis.
It’s a pause.

A moment to step back and look at how we got here and why so many things now feel strangely disconnected, confusing, or out of alignment.

If you’ve ever felt that something fundamental has drifted, but struggled to put your finger on what, this reflection is for you.
